Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2012 03:15PM slousha wrote: At the beginning when I was coming to the waiting room of Cancer Institute in noticed a lot of ladies with beautiful hairdo. I thought they fixed the hair because visiting doctors. Weeks later practiced my own wig I discovered that all these ladies were wearing wigs! And the people not knowing about my BC admired my new hair cut! Chin up, dear Joan!

Sometimes I've had hard times, cancer is still every day in my mind, and I'm seeing many ladies following the same proceeding... Wishing all of us the best for the future! Usha from Europe

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 07:08AM slousha wrote: Hi buburuzaa,  Taxotere injures the gastrointestinal mucous membranes. Salt and soda could be too severe for her. Try sage tee - salvia officinalis - I was rinsing my mouth to ten times a day, haven't had any difficulties. Paracetamol was proposed for pains as the least risky. Best Usha
Posts.Title: Good news with taxotere? krissi Momine

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 07:09PM slousha wrote: hi buburuzaa, Was your mother told to rinse her mouths with aseptic or sage tea all time of chemo and to take pain killer in case of need? Side effects of chemo at 5-6 day were usually for me too. Hugs and best wishes for 2012! Usha
Posts.Title: Good news with taxotere? krissi Momine

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2011 07:36AM slousha wrote: Hi crissy, I'm coming from a little state in Middle Europe and my first onco-radiologist at Core Needle Biopsy said: If you decided for healing, you will get the same proceeding as the patient in USA, England but Germany. I was found triple positive after my lumpectomy, accepted the complete medical treatment, (6x chemo with Docetaxel (Taxotere), 30 rads, one year on Herceptin),  I'm on Femara (Letrozole) for 5 years now. I have had 6 rounds Taxotere with Herceptin last year. I got premedication before starting the infusions,  was pretreated with corticosteroids (Medrol) to prevent SE‘s (one day prior to the treatment and three days after. It was tolerable. During all cycles I was drinking a lot and was rinsing my mouth with aseptic (or sage tee).  I read a lot about medicines on web sides, you can find something about Taxotere on http://www.answers.com/under docetaxel. Chemo is a killing matter, but it has been reported BC patients treated wit Docetaxel have higher survival! My best wishes ! Usha
Posts.Title: Good news with taxotere? krissi Momine

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 05:40AM slousha wrote: About hair - My SIL in high position, practices in the 70' to wear a wig to have her hair done of looking well. Telling her about my referral (?) from MO to get a wig before chemo, she was excited:"How fine, I'll go with you" It was as buying a new dress. I tried some and buy it. After three weeks I lost my hair and the wig was too big, but I could change it. It was quite pretty, not from natural hair but made on the tiny fine plastic web. I wear it from Jan till Now 2010, all were saying I should always get my hair cut in this way. For all that I was wery happy to get my hair back. I wish all my BC sisters could get the same experience Greetings! (English isn't my native language)
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 12:15PM slousha wrote: Hi, Three years ago in November I was given the pathological report. Now I’m very glad because my MO has said” You don't have cancer any more. After 22 very troublesome months of Femara, my SE's are truly minor on Aromasin. Even now I’m browsing BCO posts every day. I would like cancer not to have in my mind so often, but I couldn’t to prevent me from. Congratulations! Take care and best wishes! Usha
Posts.Title: Grateful! -Celebrating My 3 Year Anniversary as a Survivor CharlotteMe hmh23

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 04:20PM slousha wrote: Ebru, A friendly nurse asking her how to cope with having cancer answered: The life is the easiest for these who are not interested in illness, not thinking about not reading about not speaking about, not looking to get information and trying to live as healthy person.. It’s much harder for them whose the first thought in the morning and the last in the evening is cancer. They will learn a lot about how to cope with, to adapt to it, to live with. They will be trying to get intimate friends, support and consolation from others in the same situation. All the best and take care Usha from Europe

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 03:49PM - edited Mar 18, 2011 03:51PM by slousha Dear brave heart, To encourage you: today is one year past my last chemo! I'm alive, my hair is back, my eyebrows a bit thinner, and I gained weight,  I can walk, I can dance, desperate days are forgotten ! But it was worth!! I‘m thankful for this long heavy heeling process!! Be kind with yourself! And remember:  Every your pain is killing cancer cells in your body!  You shouldn't be sad or desperate therefore! And look at breast cancer sites how to cope chemo SE's! Remain really brave heart! Usha

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 11:08AM slousha wrote: Hi exbrnxgrl, I really can understand you! At the day of my second chemo cycle, my youngest son introduced his girl friend to me and let me know they are getting married. At wedding day I still wore the wig, took pain killers, danced till small hours. Being in therapies yet, my sweet, tiny granddaughter was born. But I remember this period as one of happiest in all my lifetime. Congrats on the baby and best wishes for you and all yours dearest! Usha
